The Sultan maintains a sort of crime register there, an extract from which he gave to Captain Bird on his return from Egypt. B.O.A.C. with only 2 European members on their staff, had committed two breaches of the 'Local Rules for the behaviour of the Nassara' in Salalah. The R.A.F. had committed five or six petty errors. The Americans had two pages of crimes listed against them, in nearly every case the offence being that they evaded the restriction of no movement to the to to without an 'askar' in attendance. Unfortunately for then., the sultan the day before Captain Bird left Salalah, discovered that they had mysteriously acquired a habit of visiting their Radio Range which is situated one mile from the Camp,at ni^at and did not take one of His Hi^iness! askars with them. The Officer Commanding Americans had on more than one occasion been warned by the Assistant Political Agent of the consequence if the Sultan discovered that they were 'hinting' in the Radio Range, the sultan threatened to report the matter to the American authorities in the Middle East. Against this he was successfully persuaded by Captain Bird, because the then Commanding Officer, with all his faults, is ideal from the point of view of Anglo-American relations on the Camp* and very different fran his predecessor, who was considered by /manymany to be Hitler’s greatest asset on the South Arabian Air Route*

titleInfo.title: Coll 5/82 ‘Facilities for U.S. Transport Corps at Sharjah; Posting of U.S. Provost Personnel for & maintenance of Discipline’

physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in approximate chronological order from the rear to the front of the file.

Foliation: the foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 13; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio.

mods.abstract: The file contains a small number of papers related to a suggestion, made by the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf in a telegram dated 15 August 1944 (folio 11), for the appointment of Provost (military police) personnel to maintain discipline among the increasing number of United States Army Air Force (USAAF) personnel at Sharjah.The file includes a divider which gives a list of correspondence references contained in the file by year. This is placed at the back of the correspondence.
